title: Cait Harrigan, MSc.
text: I am a graduate student at the University of Toronto supervised by Quaid Morris and Kieran Campbell. I‚Äôm a graduate researcher at the Vector Institute and Doctoral Fellow at the UofT Data Sciences Institute. I use machine learning to understand cancer genomics by modelling the evolutionary constraints that underlie how mutations occur in DNA. I‚Äôm passionate about open science, and promoting great mentorship in the sciences.

title: Cait Harrigan, MSc.
text:
Mentorship
As part of my ongoing commitment to supporting students at all levels and background in engaging with computational biology, I make an effort to be available to provide guidance and resources to students, with a particular focus on creating an inclusive environment that fosters diverse perspectives and experiences. In addition to being a mentor through the organized programs listed here, I set aside ~2h/month for by-request 30 minute meetings.



DCS Alumni-Student Mentorship Program

Computer Science Alumni Mentorship Program

title: Hi, I‚Äôm Cait
text:
I am a graduate student at the University of Toronto supervised by Quaid Morris and Kieran Campbell, and a graduate researcher at the Vector Institute and Ontario Institute for Cancer Research. I use machine learning to understand cancer evolution.
I did my undergraduate studies at the University of Toronto, in Computational Biology and Statistics. I‚Äôm passionate about open science, and promoting great mentorship in the sciences.
I like to drink coffee and go hiking ‚òï üèîÔ∏è ‚òÄÔ∏è

Testimonials

‚ÄúI was fortunate to work with Cait for almost a year and had a wonderful experience. She was patient, supportive, and skilled at explaining complicated concepts in biology and programming. As a mentor, she has a great sense of when to guide you through a problem and when to let you work through challenges on your own. She helped me grow as a researcher and writer and I‚Äôm grateful for everything I learned from her.‚Äù


‚ÄúAs a mentor, Caitlin has greatly enhanced my ability to conduct research. She also provided valuable resources and aimed to make sure that I understood the fundamental concepts behind all the research conducted by breaking down difficult principles into easily comprehensible statements and thoughts. Additionally, she helped me find any sources of error as the research progressed. I enjoyed researching under her guidance, and I had an overall positive experience.‚Äù

title: Ode to Zotero
text:
Zotero is my citation manager. I love it, here‚Äôs why.

It‚Äôs open source
It‚Äôs lightweight
It syncs with overleaf
It has excellent search
One click to save from brower
It syncs to the cloud
Customizable bibliography formats

More reasons to love:

Lots of free storage
Integreations with Word, Google docs, etc
The project folders are great for organizing research
Automatic report generation with all your notes
Group-libraries for collaboration
A cute timeline generator




You can see the year I got excited about genomics from my Zotero timeline

title: Writing strategies for Canadian scholarships
text:
This is my attempt to compile what I‚Äôve learned about writing though applying for government scholarships. Most of it comes from my own trial and error, but some I also picked up from workshops, and by looking at other people‚Äôs proposals.
Special thanks to Shawn Goyal, Silvia Sellan, Amit Deshwar, Trevor Stirling, Jeff Wintersinger, Sam Killackey for helpful advice they‚Äôve shared with me
I‚Äôm not a trained writer, and I definitely haven‚Äôt won all the awards I‚Äôve ever applied to. This is really just a list of strategies that I use when writing, some of which might be helpful, some not. They are all aimed at building technical project proposals, with a bias towards NSERC because that‚Äôs the agency that my work falls under.
Additionally, keep in mind that I‚Äôm writing this at a particular moment in time. In preparing this post, I‚Äôve been really surprised by how different the expectations were on student applications, just 5 years ago. I think that my writing algorithm is pertty gerneralizable (I have used it for both technical writing, and personal statements), but I can‚Äôt anticipate how the requirements might change in the future.





Important: do the following things in this order

Set up page margins to 2cm
Set font to 12pt Arial
Write document title and your name in the header. Don‚Äôt forget to paginate where appropriate.
Paste the instructions into the document, anything that gives guidelines on what the content should be. Check back on these as you write, especially if you get stuck on what to write about.
Write a bullet point outline of all the ideas you want to include (past, present, future work, practical implementation, etc)
Write statement-style headers for each section, in a way that captures the narrative flow of the story. These headers should be written such that they are sufficient that someone reading them could explain your whole project, even though you haven‚Äôt written the content yet. Put them in bold.
Assign the bullet points to headers. These will guide how you flush out the body text.
Write the content paragraphs. Don‚Äôt worry about writing them in order. If you have trouble making progress on one, write a shabby skeleton the best you can, and move on to a different section. The headers from step 5 will give you a strong sense of which chunks of text are self-contained.
Edit. Go back to any paragraphs that are not flowing correctly. Use a read-aloud service (ex. MS word) to listen to your draft.
Realize you‚Äôre about 20% over the page limit. Change font to 12pt Times New Roman. Now you‚Äôre done.


I am writing this in 2021. The specific formatting instructions might have changed since then. Never listen to anyone about presentation standards, except the official instructions.
Steps 4-6 should only contain sentence fragments and ideas that are easy to write. Do not spend time agonizing over wording in these steps.


I learned #6 by reading other people‚Äôs Vanier examples. Done correctly, your headers will improve the readability of your documents. This will be the thing that makes your application skimmable. This is important, because your application will be one of a large number of others that reviewers will have to read through.
Another critical trick for me is to always draft in Arial before finalizing to Times New Roman. TNR is significantly more condensed, and this font conversion will gift you extra space, as long as you don‚Äôt start by writing in it. I tend to over-write, and this trick helps me avoid having to spend a lot of time cutting content.
When it comes to getting the exact wording you want, don‚Äôt let perfect be the enemy of progress. When you get stuck on a word:

Use a thesaurus
Look at other writing samples (some of mine are available here)
Write down a few synonyms of the word you‚Äôre trying to find as a note to self and come back to it later.




This is just one structure example, which I have followed with success in the past. There are many other equally effective other structuring approaches.
There are a few points in this structure that are subtly distinct. You should not just paraphrase the same sentence twice for these, which is a pitfall I‚Äôve been prone to. These elements have different roles in the proposal. I have highlighted pairs of elements in this structure should not get conflated. Distinguish them from each other by changing the scope of what they describe, or where they fall on a timeline spanning from ‚Äúyour project‚Äù to ‚Äúwe aquired all knowledge in the field‚Äù.

Background and motivation

Where we are now (state of the field)
What‚Äôs needed (key steps in new knowledge generation)

Objectives and hypothesis

What you‚Äôre developing (one liner)
What it will enable (big picture impact of your results)

Knowledge gap (The direction your results will take the field in. Keep it large enough scale/scope that your project does not completely fill this gap, but maybe your project, plus 3-5 years more research would.)
Significance (Implications of what your project will enable)
Experimental and theoretical approach

Summary of 2-3 goals. Goals should describe the overarching themes of what your results will show.
2-3 aims, with substeps that build to each aim. Aims should be actionable steps you will take, and build on each other logically, however later aims should not strictly rely on the success of earlier aims in order to be possible to execute. (What would you do if the early stuff didn‚Äôt work out? You don‚Äôt want to leave your proposal vulnerable to that question.)

Why you are uniquely positioned to execute the research here and now

The biggest challenge for early-PhDs is not yet having a super strong grasp on the state of their field, and how their project fits in that context. Probably your PI has a good idea of this, and they may have an overarching research story that you can tap into. The only other thing you can do to improve on this is to read widely and engage with other researchers in your field. This is more of a student-lifestyle thing than it is writing advice, but it‚Äôs what makes for a good researcher (and subsequently, research proposal).



If you‚Äôre not already using a citation management tool, then your life is harder than it needs to be. I use Zotero, but many favour Mendeley, or Paperpile.

I explain all the reasons I love Zotero in this post.




As a serial procrastinator, this is the piece of advice that I always hated hearing. Obviously no one wants to fall into last minute panic, it just happens.
Don‚Äôt expect to nail it on the first try.
The easiest thing to work off of is your own past writing samples. You can steal full sentences from them without plagerizing, and it‚Äôs always in your own words üòå

title: Writing strategies for Canadian scholarships
section: Create a draft that harmonizes with your reference letters
text:
Create a draft that harmonizes with your reference letters
A common recipe that I have noticed in the successful applications that I‚Äôve seen (and tried to model in my own application) to prove that your leadership is ‚Äúabove and beyond‚Äù goes along these lines:

You have a series of examples of times you were in a leadership position, and did something extra

You made the leadership position your own in some way
You took an active role in supporting others
You created something new to solve a problem

Between your two reference letters, all the examples you listed are repeated, but discussed from a different perspective

Your referees identify the impact of the ‚Äúsomething extra‚Äù that you did
Your referees are able to explain why what you did made others admire/respect/be grateful to you
Your referees have a lot of positive adjectives to describe your character

title: Writing strategies for Canadian scholarships
section: Have a clear idea of your career direction
text:
Have a clear idea of your career direction

It‚Äôs not bragging to say you want to be an amazing professional.
anchor the story

title: Writing strategies for Canadian scholarships
section: Offer to draft your referee‚Äôs letters for them
text:
Offer to draft your referee‚Äôs letters for them
This will make it a lot easier for your referees to agree to be a reference for you. It will also let you have a hand in what your letters look like, and ensure that they suport your personal leadership statement.

Bonus tip: I avoid using the phrase ‚Äúreference letter‚Äù because that sounds to me like a neutral term. Your referees should absolutely not be neutral about you! The phrase I prefer is ‚Äúendorsement letter‚Äù. This sounds more positive overall, and is a good way to signal to your referees what you are asking for from them. A reference letter that is not an endorsement is not useful to you anyways.

title: Writing strategies for Canadian scholarships
section: Leave a full day for formatting
text:
Leave a full day for formatting
Do not underestimate the time sink that is uploading all your files, reuploading, editing the CCV because of a missing comma, reuploading, now there‚Äôs an extra comma, reuploading, etc.
The first time you put everything into the CCV system is the most painful. After that it is easier :)
